text:
Introduction
This is a book on the history of calligraphy and calligraphers. It is an extension of ancient works, most notably the book "Adab al-Kuttab" by Muhammad bin Yahya al-Suli who died in the year 336 AH, long chapters in the "Fihrist" of Ibn al-Nadim who died in the year 385 AH, and "Subh al-A'sha" by al-Qalqashandi who died in the year 821 AH.
Sayyid Murtada al-Zabidi authored this book to include "the virtue of calligraphy and the pen and the traditions (Athar) reported about them, the secrets the wise have regarding them, an explanation of who first established the script and composed the letters, clothed them in the robes of detail and placed them in the best of conditions, and then an explanation of the illustrious writers and notables of the art."
He made this treatise a gift to the library of the genius of calligraphy, Prince Hassan Effendi, nicknamed al-Rushdi (1).
He divided it into ten chapters and a conclusion:
Chapter One: On the mention of who established the script and its origin, and who connected and separated it.
Chapter Two: On the virtue of calligraphy and what has been said about it.
Chapter Three: On the pen, and their wisdom regarding it.
foot_note: 1. He is Hassan Effendi bin Abdullah, nicknamed al-Rushdi, of Roman origin. He died in the same year al-Zabidi died. Al-Jabarti said in his biography: "The freed slave of Ali Agha Bashir Dar al-Sa'ada, the Egyptian scribe. His master bought him when he was young, disciplined him, trained him, and occupied him with calligraphy, so he strove in it. He perfected it under Abdullah al-Anis, and the day of his Ijazah (certification) was a precious gathering that brought together subordinates and chiefs. Then he married him to his daughter and made him his successor. He remained during his master's life devoted to practice and drafting, caring for editing and improvement until he surpassed the people of his time in quality in the art... And when the Sheikh of the two offices, the late Ismail al-Wahbi died, the translator (biographee) was made Sheikh by their agreement... And for his sake, our Sheikh Sayyid Muhammad Murtada authored the book 'Hikmat al-Ishraq ila Kitab al-Afaq'... He remained a Sheikh and spokesman for the group of calligraphers and writers, and their dean who is pointed out among the masters. He copied with his hand several Qurans and Hizbs (portions). As for copies of Dalail al-Khayrat, their abundance cannot be counted, until death circumambulated him the farewell circumambulation, and scattered the necklace of that gathering. And with his death, the order of this art became extinct." Tarikh al-Jabarti 2: 211.

Sayyid Murtada al-Zabidi
Sayyid Murtada al-Zabidi was a venerable linguist scholar from the scholars of the thirteenth century. Al-Jabarti devoted a precious biography to him in his history, most of which I preferred to transmit in his wording and arrangement, keen on the complete depiction it contains of this man's life and his connections with the men of his era.
Al-Jabarti said in his biography (1): Our Sheikh, the flag of flags, and the magician playing with understandings, who roamed every path in language and Hadith, and waded into every depth of knowledge, the one for whom the paths of speech were humbled, and to whom paper and pens testify, the possessor of knowledge and the well-known, and he is the described flag, the reliable, the very understanding, the traveler, the genealogist, the jurist, the Muhaddith, the linguist, the grammarian, the Usuli (scholar of principles), the poet, the prose writer, Sheikh Abu al-Fayd Sayyid Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Abd al-Razzaq, famous as Murtada al-Husseini al-Zabidi (2) al-Hanafi. This is how he mentioned about himself and his lineage. He was born in the year 1145 AH as I heard it from his utterance and saw it in his handwriting. He grew up in his country and traveled seeking knowledge and performed Hajj multiple times. He met Sheikh Abdullah al-Sindi, Sheikh Umar bin Ahmad bin Aqil al-Makki, Abdullah al-Saqqaf, the Musnid Muhammad Ibn Ala al-Din al-Mizjaji, Sulayman bin Yahya, and Ibn al-Tayyib. He met Sayyid Abd al-Rahman al-Aydarus in Mecca, and Sheikh Abdullah Mirghani al-Taifi in the year sixty-three. He stayed in Taif after going to Yemen and returning in the year sixty-six. He read Fiqh with Sheikh Abdullah and many of his works, and he granted him Ijazah. He read the Mukhtasar of al-Sa'd with Sheikh Abd al-Rahman al-Aydarus, accompanied him closely, and he dressed him in the (Khirqa) and granted him Ijazah for his narrations and what he heard. He said: "He is the one who made me yearn to enter Egypt by what he described to me of its scholars, princes, and litterateurs, and the noble shrines therein, so my soul longed to see it, and I came with the caravan, and what happened happened." He read part of the Ihya with him, and he granted him Ijazah for his narrations.

1. See Aja'ib al-Athar 2: 196 - 210 in the events of the year 1205 AH. This biography was summarized by Al-Shiblanji in Nur al-Absar 214, and Ali Mubarak in Al-Khitat al-Tawfiqiyya 3: 93 - 94. 
2. Attributed to Zabid, with a Fatha on the Zay, which is a famous city in Yemen.

text: Then he arrived in Egypt on the ninth of Safar in the year 1167 AH and lived in Khan al-Saghah. The first person he associated with and took knowledge from was Sayyid Ali al-Maqdisi al-Hanafi, one of the scholars of Egypt. He attended the lessons of the sheikhs of the time such as Sheikh Ahmad al-Mallawi, al-Jawhari, al-Hifni, al-Bulaydi, al-Sa'idi, al-Mudabighi, and others. He received knowledge from them, and they granted him Ijazah and testified to his knowledge, virtue, and quality of memorization. The "Katkhuda of Azban (1)" took care of his affairs and bestowed his kindness upon him until his affair became popular, his condition flourished, and his mention became famous among the elite and the general public. He wore luxurious clothes and rode marked horses. He traveled to Upper Egypt three times and met its grandees, notables, and scholars. Sheikh of the Arabs Hamam, Ismail Abu Abdullah, Abu Ali, the children of Nusayr, and the children of Wafi honored him, gave him gifts, and treated him kindly. Likewise, he traveled to the coastal regions such as Damietta, Rosetta, Mansoura, and the rest of the great towns multiple times when they were adorned with their people and populated by their grandees. Everyone honored him, and he met the grandees of the regions and the masters of knowledge and behavior (Sufism). He received from them, and they granted him Ijazah and he granted them Ijazah. He authored (several travelogues) about his movements in the southern and northern lands containing anecdotes, dialogues, and praises in verse and prose that, if collected, would make a huge volume. Our master Abu al-Anwar bin Wafa gave him the Kunya (Abu al-Fayd), and that was on Tuesday, the seventeenth of Sha'ban in the year 1182 AH, in the courtyards of our masters Bani al-Wafa on the day of the customary Mawlid visit. Then he married and lived in Atfat al-Ghassal while keeping his residence in Wikalat al-Saghah. He began (explaining al-Qamus) until he completed it in several years in about fourteen volumes, naming it "Taj al-Arus". When he completed it, he (held a lavish banquet) in which he gathered students of knowledge and sheikhs of the time in Ghayt al-Ma'diyah, and that was in the year 1181 AH. He showed it to them, and they rejoiced in it and testified to his merit, breadth of knowledge, and firmness in the science of language. They wrote their commendations on it in prose and verse." Then al-Jabarti listed the names of these commenders and some of their commendations, then said: "When Muhammad Bey Abu al-Dhahab established his mosque known by his name near al-Azhar and made a library in it, and bought a number of books and placed them there, they informed him about this explanation of al-Qamus and told him that if it were placed in the library, its system would be complete, and it would be unique in that over others. They encouraged him in that, so he requested it and compensated him for it with one hundred thousand silver dirhams, and placed it there.
foot_note: 1. The meaning of Katkhuda: Minister of Internal Affairs, as stated in Takhlis al-Ibriz by Rifa'a al-Tahtawi p. 72.

text: The subject (of the biography) continued to serve knowledge and ascend the degrees of highness, keen on collecting the arts that the later scholars neglected, such as the science of genealogies, chains of transmission (Isnad), graduation (Takhrij) of Hadiths, and connecting the methods of later Muhaddiths with the earlier ones. He authored many books, treatises, poems, and Rajaz verses on that. Then he moved to a house in Suwayqat al-Lala, opposite the mosque of Muharram Effendi, near the mosque of Shams al-Din al-Hanafi. That was in the early part of the year 1189 AH. That area was then populated by grandees and notables, so they surrounded him, and he endeared himself to them, and they became familiar with him, comforted him, and gave him gifts. He showed them richness and abstinence, preached to them, benefited them with benefits, amulets, and Ruqyahs, and granted them Ijazah to read litanies and Hizbs. So they came to him from every direction, and came to visit him from every side, desiring his company because he was a stranger and not in the image or form of Egyptian scholars. (He knew Turkish and Persian languages), and even some of the Georgian language. So their hearts were attracted to him, and they transmitted his news and speech. Then he began dictating Hadith in the manner of the Salaf, mentioning chains of transmission, narrators, and graduators from his memory in different ways. To everyone who came to him, he would dictate the Hadith patterned with firstness (Musalsal bil-Awwaliyyah), which is the Hadith of Mercy, with its narrators and graduators, and write for him a Sanad (chain) for that, an Ijazah, and the hearing of those present, so they would marvel at that. Then some of the scholars of (Al-Azhar) went to him and asked him for Ijazah. He said to them: The beginnings of the books must be read. They agreed to meet at the mosque of Shaykhun in al-Saliba on Mondays and Thursdays to be away from people. So they began Sahih al-Bukhari with the reading of Sayyid Hussein al-Shaykhuni. Some people of the area gathered with them, along with Sheikh Musa al-Shaykhuni, the Imam of the mosque and librarian, who was a great man respected by the people of the area and others. People circulated the news of the pursuit of Al-Azhar scholars like Sheikh Ahmad al-Sajja'i, Sheikh Mustafa al-Ta'i, Sheikh Sulayman al-Akrashi, and others to take from him. So his status increased and his worth became great. The people of those areas and others, from the commoners, grandees, and notables, gathered around him and requested him to explain the meanings, so he moved from narration (Riwaya) to comprehension (Diraya), and it became a great lesson. At that point, most of the Azharites stopped attending, and he also dispensed with them. He began dictating to the group, after reading something from the Sahih, a hadith from the Musalsalat or the virtues of deeds, listing the men of its chain and its narrators from his memory and following it (with verses of poetry) as well. So they would marvel at that because they were not accustomed to it previously from Egyptian teachers.

text: He opened another lesson in the Hanafi mosque, and read Al-Shama'il on days other than the usual ones after Asr prayer. So his fame increased, and people came from every side to hear him and see his person, because it was contrary to the appearance and dress of the Egyptians. Many notables invited him to their homes and held lavish banquets for him. He would go to them with the elite students, the reciter, the dictation writer (Mustamli), and the name writer. He would read to them something from the Hadith parts like the Thulathiyyat of Al-Bukhari or Al-Darimi, or some Musalsalat, in the presence of the group, the owner of the house, his companions, loved ones, children, (and his daughters and women from behind curtains). Before them were incense burners with ambergris and oud for the duration of the reading. Then they would conclude that with prayers upon the Prophet, peace be upon him, in the usual manner. The writer would write the names of the attendees and listeners, even women, boys, and girls, and the day and date, and the Sheikh would write under that: "That is correct." This was the method of the Muhaddiths in the past times as we saw in old books. The humble one (the author) says: I was a witness and present in most of these gatherings and lessons, and other private gatherings in his home and his old residence in Khan al-Saghah, and our home in al-Sanadiqiyya and Bulaq and other places we used to go to for recreation like Ghayt al-Ma'diyah (and al-Azbakiyya) and other than that. We used to occupy most times reciting Hadith parts and others, which is much, with the confirmation of what was heard on the copies and in many papers existing until now. (Some great princes) were attracted to him, like Mustafa Bey al-Iskandarani and Ayyub Bey the Defterdar. So they sought his home: and frequented the attendance of his lesson gatherings. They continued giving him abundant gifts and grains. He bought slave girls, made food for guests, and honored comers and arrivals from distant horizons. Abdul Razzaq Effendi the Chief came from the Roman lands to Egypt and heard of him, so he came to him and requested Ijazah from him and reading the Maqamat of Al-Hariri. He used to go to him after finishing the lesson of Shaykhun and study for him what was easy of the Maqamat, and he would explain to him their linguistic meanings. When Muhammad Pasha Izzat the Great arrived, he raised his status with him and elevated him to himself, and bestowed upon him a sable fur coat. He arranged for him an allocation from his pantry for his sufficiency, of meat, ghee, rice, firewood, and bread. He arranged for him a plentiful stipend in the register of the Two Holy Mosques and the convoy, and grains from the granary. He reported his status to the State, so a decree came to him with a plentiful salary from the Mint, amounting to one hundred and fifty silver halves every day, and that was in the year 1191 AH. So his affair became great and his fame spread. He was invited to the State

text: in the year 94 AH, so he accepted then refused. Correspondence from the grandees of the State followed successively to him, and they continued giving him gifts, masterpieces, and precious goods in boxes. His mention flew in the horizons, and kings of the regions wrote to him, from the Turks, Hejaz, India, Yemen, Sham, Basra, Iraq, and the kings of Morocco, Sudan, Fezzan, Algeria, and distant lands. Delegations to him increased from every side, and gifts, connections, and strange things followed successively from them to him. They sent him sheep from Fezzan, which are of strange creation and huge body, their head resembles the head of a calf. He sent them to the children of Sultan Abdul Hamid, and they were well received. Likewise, they sent him parrots, slave girls, slaves, and eunuchs. He used to send from the novelties of one region to the region where that is considered strange, and multiples of it would come to him in return. Precious things came to him from the novelties of India, Sana'a, Yemen, Sirte lands, and others, and Kadi water, jams, oud, ambergris, and Attar Shah by the pounds. He gained great fame, high status, and excessive belief among the people of Morocco. They might have believed him to have (the Great Qutbiyya/Poleship) such that if one of them arrived in Egypt as a pilgrim and did not visit him or connect with him with something, his Hajj would not be complete. If one of them came to him, he would ask him about his name, title, country, area, profession, and children, and memorize that or write it down. He would ask this one about that with kindness and gentleness. If a comer came to him the next year, he would ask him about his name and country, so he would say to him: So-and-so from such town. It would not be without him either knowing him from someone else previously, or knowing his neighbor or relative, so he would say to him: Is So-and-so well? He would say: Yes, my master. Then he would ask him about his brother So-and-so, his son So-and-so, his wife, and his daughter, and indicate to him the name of his neighborhood, his house, and what is next to it. So that Moroccan would stand up and sit down, kiss the ground once and prostrate once, and believe that this is from the clear unveiling (Kashf). You would see them in the days of the Hajj ascent and descent crowding at his door from morning to sunset. Everyone who entered among them presented something before his private conversation, either weighed silver, dates, or candles, according to his poverty or wealth. Some of them would come to him with correspondence and connections from the people of his country, its scholars, and notables, requesting answers from him. Whoever among them obtained a piece of paper, even the size of a fingertip, it was as if he obtained a good ending. He would keep it with him like an amulet, and consider that his Hajj had been accepted, otherwise he would have returned with disappointment and regret, and blame would be directed at him from the people of his country, and his regret would last until the day of his appointment. Measure upon that what has not been said. He began explaining (Ihya' 'Ulum al-Din) by al-Ghazali, and wrote fair copies of parts of it and sent some to Rome (Turkey), Sham, and the West so it would become famous like the explanation of al-Qamus and people would desire to request and copy it.

text: And (his wife died) in the year 96 AH, so he grieved for her greatly. He buried her at the shrine known as the Shrine of Sayyida Ruqayya, and built a maqam (structure), enclosure, curtains, furnishings, and lamps over her grave. He stayed at her grave for many days. People, reciters, and singers would gather with him, and he would make food, Tharid, couscous, coffee, and sherbet for them. He bought a place next to the mentioned cemetery, built a small house on it, furnished it, and housed her mother in it, and he would sleep there sometimes. Poets aimed at him with elegies, and he would accept that from them and reward them for it. He eulogized her with poems I found in his handwriting after his death in his scattered papers, in the style of the poetry of Majnun Layla." Al-Jabarti cited six pieces by al-Zabidi eulogizing her, then said: "Then he married another after her, who is the one he left behind when he died and who acquired what he collected of wealth and other things. When he reached the ultimate fame, far-reaching reputation, and great value and status among the elite and general public, and delegations came to him from all regions, and the world came to him in its entirety from every side, he stuck to his house and veiled himself from his companions whom he used to meet before that, except rarely for some purpose. He left lessons and teaching, secluded himself inside the Harem, locked the door, and overtly rejected the gifts coming to him from the Egyptian grandees. Ayyub Bey the Defterdar once sent him with his son fifty Ardabs of wheat, and loads of rice, ghee, honey, and oil, and five hundred Riyals cash, and bundles of clothing of Indian fabrics and broadcloth and other things, but he returned them. That was in Ramadan. Likewise, Mustafa Bey al-Iskandarani and others came to him, but he veiled himself from them and did not come out to them, and they returned without meeting him face to face. When Hasan Pasha arrived in the manner he arrived in Egypt, he (al-Zabidi) did not go to him; rather, he (Hasan Pasha) came to visit him. He (al-Zabidi) bestowed upon him a fur coat suitable for him, and presented him with a prepared, trained horse with a saddle and abaya, valued at a thousand dinars, which he had prepared and readied before that. His intercession with him was not rejected. If he sent him a message regarding something, he received it with acceptance and reverence, kissed the paper before reading it, placed it on his head, and executed what was in it. Once he sent a letter to Ahmad Pasha al-Jazzar mentioning in it that he is (the Awaited Mahdi) and will have a great affair. It was received by him as truth due to the inclination of souls towards desires. He placed that letter in his amulet that he wore along with charms and talismans. He used to show that to some who came to him claiming knowledge in Jafas and Zaijahs and believed its authenticity without doubt. Whoever came to him from the direction of Egypt and asked him about the translator (al-Zabidi), if he told him and informed him that he met him and took

from him and mentioned him with praise and commendation, he loved him, honored him, and gave him a generous gift. If the opposite happened from him, he frowned at him, excluded him, distanced him, and withheld his kindness from him, even if he was a person of virtue. This became famous among those who knew that from him by physiognomy. He remained having a good opinion of the translator (al-Zabidi) until both passed away. It happened that Mawlay Muhammad, Sultan of Morocco, may Allah have mercy on him, connected with him with gifts before his final seclusion and asceticism, and he accepted them with praise, commendation, and supplication. He sent him in the year 1201 a gift of value, but he returned it and abstained from accepting it, and it was lost and did not return to the Sultan. The Sultan knew that from his answer, so he sent him a letter I read, which I had then was lost in papers. Its content was blame and rebuke for returning the gift. He says to him: You returned the gift we sent you from the treasury of Muslims. Would that, since you abstained from it, you had distributed it to the poor and needy, so we and you would have the reward for that, but you returned it and it was lost. (He also blames him) for his explanation of the book Al-Ihya, saying to him: You should have occupied your time with something beneficial other than that. He mentions the reason for his blame of him in that and what the scholars said, and silencing, brief, useful words. May Allah have mercy on him. The translator (al-Zabidi) has many compositions other than Sharh al-Qamus (1) and Sharh al-Ihya (2), including:
1 - Kitab al-Jawahir al-Munifah, fi Usul Adillat Madhhab al-Imam Abu Hanifa (The Lofty Jewels, on the Principles of Evidences of the School of Imam Abu Hanifa), may Allah be pleased with him, regarding what the six Imams agreed upon (3). It is a precious, full book he arranged in the order of Hadith books by presenting what was narrated from him in beliefs then in actions according to the order of Fiqh books.
2 - Al-Nafha al-Qudsiyya, bi-Wasitat al-Bid'a al-Aydarusiyya (The Holy Breath, through the Aydarus Part), in which he collected the chains of transmission of al-Aydarus, and it is in about ten fascicles.
3 - Al-Iqd al-Thamin, fi Turuq al-Ilbas wal-Talqin (The Precious Necklace, on the Methods of Clothing (the Sufi cloak) and Instruction).
4 - Hikmat al-Ishraq ila Kitab al-Afaq (The Wisdom of Illumination for the Book of Horizons).

Chapter: On the mention of who established the script and its origin, and who connected and separated it
It is said: The first to establish script and all books was Adam, peace be upon him, three hundred years before his death. He wrote them in clay and baked it. When the drowning led the people astray, every people found their book.
It is said: The first to establish it was Enoch, who is Idris, peace be upon him.
It is said that Nafis (1), Nasr (2), Tayma, and Dumah, sons of Ismail, established one script and made it one connected line, not separated, all letters connected. Then Nabt (3), Hamaysa, and Qaydar separated it, separated the letters, and made the similarities.
As for the Arabic script, the first to establish it and compose its letters were six persons from Tasm, who were staying with Adnan bin Udad. Their names were: Abjad, Hawwaz, Hutti, Kalamun, Sa'fas, Qarashat. They established writing and script based on their names. When they found letters in words that were not in their names, they appended them to them, and called them the Ruwadif (followers), which are Thakhadh, Dazagh.
It is said: The first to establish Arabic script was Muramir bin Murrah (4), and it is said, Amir bin Jadrah - the author of al-Qamus mentioned each of them - and it is said Aslam bin Sidrah. They were a group from

Some scholars said (1): Handwriting is like the spirit in the body. If a person is beautiful, handsome, and of good appearance, he is greater in the eyes and more magnificent in the souls. And with the opposite of that, souls tire of him. Likewise, handwriting, if it is of good description, pleasant arrangement, open eyes, smooth texts, much harmony, little difference, souls delight in it and spirits desire it, such that a person reads it - even if it contains base speech and bad meaning - seeking more of it even if it is much, without boredom or annoyance affecting him. And if the handwriting is ugly, understandings reject it, eyes and thoughts cast it away, and its reader tires of it even if it contains the wonders of wisdom and the oddities of expressions.
It is said: The weight of handwriting is like the weight of reading; the best handwriting is the clearest, just as the best reading is the clearest (2). Chapter: On the Pen, and their wisdom regarding it
It is said: It is the first thing Allah Almighty created, and with its mention He began in the Quran, saying Almighty: "Who taught by the pen. Taught man that which he knew not." And He Almighty said: "Nun. By the pen and what they inscribe."
So He, Glory be to Him and Exalted, clarified that the craft of the pen is the best of crafts (1), and the most glorious of goods.
It is said: It is not called a pen (Qalam) until it is sharpened (Yubra), otherwise it is a reed (Qasabah). A spear is not called a spear unless it has a head, otherwise it is a shaft (Qanat). A table is not called a table (Ma'idah) unless it has food on it, otherwise it is a tray (Khiwan). A cup is not called a cup (Ka's) unless it has drink in it, otherwise it is a glass (Zujajah).
Some of the Greek kings said (2): The affair of the world and religion falls under two things: a sword and a pen, and the sword is under the pen.
Abu al-Fath al-Busti said:
If heroes swear one day by their sword... And count it among what earns glory and generosity
It suffices the pen of scribes in glory and loftiness... For eternity that Allah swore by the pen (3)
Alexander said: What pens have established, days have not coveted to erase.
It is said: The pen is the tongue of sight, and the mount of thought.

Ishaq bin Hammad said: The pen to the writer is like the sword to the brave.
Al-Dahhak bin Ajlan said: O you who undertake writing, gather your heart when you strike the pen, for it is only your mind that you are displaying.
As for its state in hardness and softness, it follows the paper. Because if it is soft, it needs the tube (Unbub) to have softness, its flesh to have excess, and its skin to have hardness. If it is hard, it needs the tube to have dryness and hardness. He said: The reason for that is that its need for ink on soft paper is greater than its need for it on hard paper. The Sheikh of this craft, Imad al-Din al-Shirazi (2), said: The most praiseworthy pens are those whose states are moderate in length and shortness, thickness and thinness. For the thin, slender one, the fingertips gather on it, so it remains inclined to what is between the three, and the excessively thick one is not carried by the fingertips.
Ibn al-Zayyat said (3): The best of pens is what has matured firmly, its seed has lightened, reached its prime, and straightened.

Chapter: On the inkwell, its description, and its tools
Al-Hasan bin Wahb said (1): The way of the inkwell is to be moderate in its size, not small so its pens become short and ugly, nor thick so its carrying becomes heavy.
Al-Fadl said: It should be made from the best woods and highest in price, like Ebony, Sasim, and Sandalwood (2).
As for the (Juna - pot) in which the ink container is, it should be a round-headed shape, meeting at two right angles. It should not be square in any case, because if it is square, the ink thickens. If it is round, it is purer for the ink (3) and happier in supplying ink. One should strive in improving, perfecting, and maintaining it. Al-Mada'ini recited (4):
Perfect your inkwell and strive to maintain it... For inkwells are the treasuries of manners
Among its tools is the (Liqa - threads/fiber put in inkwell), and it is made of silk, cotton, and wool. The Arabs called all that Kursuf.
Some of them said (5): Whoever does not do well in supplying ink, sharpening the pen, splitting, cutting,

Ibn al-Afif said: Whoever does not know the face of the pen, its chest, and its width, is nothing in writing (1).
Another said (2): According to the writer's ability to rotate his pen and the speed of his hand in turning, the purity of the essence of his letters will be (3).
If the writer takes ink, let the pen be in his fingers in the form of his holding it during writing, and let him not turn it to take ink, because the best method in it is to be in the writer's hand in its position for writing. He moves the head of the pen from the inside of his hand to its outside, for he can maintain the pen's position in the fingers with it. When he deviates from this, hardship befalls him in transferring the finger positioning in every dip. This is one of the greatest things a writer needs, because this is what the quality of handwriting revolves around. Rarely does the knowledge of this inform you except seeing it from a scholar skilled (4) in the geometry of handwriting, along with what accompanies him of deliberation and good performance.
Some writers said: It is incumbent on the writer to inspect the Liqa and scent it with the best available, for it changes over the long term. And he recited:
A witty person, his inkwell testified against him... That the young man was never other than witty

Some writers used to scent their inkwell with some of the perfume they had for themselves. He was asked about that, and he said: Because we write with it the name of Allah Almighty and the name of His Prophet, peace be upon him.
Another said: It is incumbent on the writer to renew the Liqa every month, and to close the inkwell when he finishes so that nothing falls into it that spoils the writing.
Another said (1): The writer should not take too much ink, but take a moderate amount. He should not move the Liqa from its place, nor scatter with the pen (2), nor return the pen to the Liqa until he exhausts what ink is in it. He should not insert much of it into the inkwell but up to the limit of its split (3), not exceeding that to the end of the opening.
Among its tools is the (Knife), which is the blade. They said: It is not used for anything other than sharpening the pen. It is desirable to exaggerate in watering and sharpening it, to enable sharpening, so the essence of the pen becomes pure and its cut does not splinter. It is the whetstone of pens; they are sharpened with it if they become blunt, released if they stop, and gathered if they become disheveled. The best of them is what has a wide chest, a thin edge, and its handle is not separated from the grip (4), and is straight without curvature. They used to prefer the 'Uqabiyyah (Eagle-like) (5), which is the one whose chest is wider than its belly.
Among its tools is the (Milwaq - stirrer) because the inkwell is stirred with it. The best is made of Ebony, so the ink color does not change it. It should be round, conical, with a wide head and thin [end].

Chapter: On Ink (Madad) and Ink (Hibr)
It was named Madad because it aids (Yamuddu) the pen, i.e., helps it. Black was used in it over others because of its contrast to the color of the paper. No color is an opposite (1) to its companion except black and white.
Another said (2): The image of ink in eyes is black, and in insights is white. Ink is a pillar of the pillars of writing and upon it is the reliance of writers (3). They recited regarding that:
A quarter of writing is in the blackness of its ink... And a quarter is the good craft of the writers
And a quarter is from a pen whose sharpening is straight... And upon the papers is the fourth of causes (4)
Ja'far bin Muhammad looked at a young man who had ink trace on his clothes while he was hiding it from him. He said to him: O you, ink on clothes is of chivalry (5).
Ibn al-Afif said: Two things without which ink is not complete are Honey and Gum (Sabr). As for

Chapter: On Sharpening Pens
It is narrated that Al-Dahhak, when he wanted to sharpen a pen, would hide so no one would see him and say: Handwriting is all about the pen (1).
Al-Ansari, when he wanted to sharpen, would do that, and when he wanted to stand up from the Diwan, he would cut off the heads of the pens (2).
They said: Teaching sharpening is greater than teaching handwriting (3).
Ibn al-Afif said: The corruption of sharpening is from the dullness of the knife.
Some of them said (4): The quality of sharpening is half of handwriting.
It is said: Some of them (5), when taking the tube to sharpen it, would inspect it beforehand. When wanting to cut, he would pause, then investigate and pause, then cut with deliberation.
It is narrated in Ibn Muqla's handwriting: The essence of handwriting is good sharpening. Whoever does it well, handwriting becomes easy for him. Whoever's heart retains the many types of pen cutting is capable of handwriting, and only a wise person learns that.
foot_note:

2. Added in Subh al-A'sha 2: 456: "So no one sees them." 
3. Subh al-A'sha 2: 456. 
4. He is Al-Muqri Al-Ala'i Ibn Fadl Allah. Subh al-A'sha 2: 456.

Ibn Hilal said (1): Every pen whose Jilfah (nib section) is short, the script comes from it Awqas, i.e., short-necked.
Ibn al-Barbari said: Beware of clumsiness in sharpening and leaving improving it. Whoever's instrument is corrupt, his work is corrupt.
Ibn al-Afif said (2): If the sharpening is long, the script comes with it lighter, weaker, and sweeter. If it is short, the script comes purer, heavier, and stronger.
As for the description of splitting it, Ibn Hilal said: It should be in its middle, and let the thickness of both teeth be equal. He said: It is permissible for the right one to be thicker than the left, but the reverse is not permissible in any case (3).
As for cutting it, it is on descriptions: Including the inclined (Muharraf), the level (Mustawi), the upright (Qa'im), and the sloped (Musawwab). The best is the inclined with moderate inclination, and the worst is the level, because the level has less maneuverability than the inclined. Ibn al-Afif said it.
Abd al-Hamid the Scribe said to Raghban, who was writing with a pen of short sharpening: Do you want your handwriting to improve? He said: Yes. He said: Lengthen the Jilfah of your pen, thicken it, incline the cut, and direct it right. Raghban said: I did that, and my handwriting improved (4).
Ibn Muqla said to his brother: If you cut the pen, do not cut it except on a smooth, hard cutting board (Maqatt),

Chapter: On Dotting (Nuqat)
It is what indicates the letters of the alphabet, and separates between them, so Ba' is known from Tha' by it. It is said: The first to dot the Mushafs and establish Arabic grammar was Abu al-Aswad al-Du'ali, by instruction from the Commander of the Faithful Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him.
Ibn Muqla said: Dots have two forms: One is a square shape, and the other is a round shape. If there are two dots on a letter, if you wish, place one above the other, or place them together in a line. If next to that letter is a letter that is dotted, it is not permissible for the dots, if paired, to be anything but one above the other. The reason for that is that if the dots are in a line and exit their letters, confusion and ambiguity occur. If some are placed on others, each letter has its share of dots, and ambiguity is removed.

Chapter: On Vowelization (Shakl)
Some linguists said: The shape (Shakl) of letters is taken from the shackle (Shikal) of the beast, because letters are controlled and restricted by it, so their syntax is not confused, just as the beast is controlled by the shackle.
Some of them said: Adorn the strange words with restriction, and fortify them against the semblance of misspelling and distortion. It is three movements: Raf' (nominative), Nasb (accusative), and Khafd (genitive).
As for Jazm (jussive/sukoon), its form is contrary to the forms of movements, entirely circular, as if they intend by it the Mim from "Ijzim" (make jazm), and deleted the tail of the Mim for lightness.
Ibn al-Afif said: If the letter is Fathah with Tanwin, its sign is two lines above it, and between them is like the measure of one of them. If it is Dammah with Tanwin, its sign is Sin without a tail, as if you intend the beginning of "Shadid" (1). If it is Jazm, its sign is Kha' without a tail, as if you intend the beginning of "Khafif". This is the doctrine of the master Abu al-Hasan (2), and upon it are the generality of the people of the East. If it is hamzated, its sign is to fix above it an 'Ayn without a tail, due to the proximity of the exit of Hamzah from 'Ayn. He said: There must be proportion between the vowelization and the dots, and proportion of white spaces in that (3).
foot_note:
1. Subh al-A'sha 3: 163. 
2. Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Hilal, known as Ibn al-Bawwab. See p. 76. 
3. See Subh al-A'sha 3: 167.

Chapter: On the mention of the alphabet letters and their secret in determining number
Kura' said: The separated letters were called alphabet letters (Huruf al-Mu'jam) because they were ambiguous until clarified by dots.
Some astronomers said: The number of Arabic letters is twenty-eight letters, on the number of the moon's mansions. The maximum a word reaches from them with the extra letters attached to it is seven letters, on the number of the seven planets. He said: The forms of extra letters are twelve (1) on the number of the twelve zodiac signs. The extra letters are ten letters, gathered in "Sa'altumuniha".
It preceded that the total letters are twenty-eight letters. Those into which the Lam of definition (Al-) is assimilated from these letters are fourteen letters, like those hidden under the earth from the moon's mansions. The rest appear with the definition, and they are fourteen letters like the visible mansions.
It preceded that the alphabet letters are twenty-eight single letters, and Lam-Alif is composed from them, so that is twenty-nine letters. They have eighteen (2) forms, because what agreed in form, there is no benefit in mentioning its likeness, because mentioning one of the forms (1) substitutes for all of them, like Ba', Ta', and Tha', and Jim, Ha', and Kha'. These eighteen (1) forms end up single and compound, as explained in its place.

text:
Chapter: On the mention of the noble scribes
From the time of the Prophet, peace be upon him, to this time of ours, in order of arrangement and good refinement.
Those who wrote for him, peace be upon him, and were honored to serve him by writing were the four Caliphs, Amir bin Fuhayra, Abdullah bin al-Arqam, Ubayy bin Ka'b, Thabit bin Qays bin Shammas, Khalid bin Sa'id bin al-Aas, Hanzala bin al-Rabi' al-Usayyidi, Zaid bin Thabit, Muawiya bin Abi Sufyan, Shurahbil bin Hasana, and others as recorded in Al-Mawahib and Seerah books, may Allah be pleased with them all. The most adherent of them to that and most specialized in it were Zaid bin Thabit and Muawiya bin Abi Sufyan.
Then the quality of handwriting and its Jalil (large/majestic) type ended with Al-Dahhak (1) and Ishaq bin Hammad. Ibrahim al-Sijzi took the Jalil type from Ishaq, and invented from it lighter movements and better pairings, naming it the Two-Thirds Pen (Qalam al-Thuluthayn). Then he invented from this pen what is lighter than it and more fluent, naming it the Third Pen (Qalam al-Thuluth). Sheikh Imad al-Din Muhammad bin al-Afif said: By this pen and the Naskh pen, the capability of the writer in his craft is known.
Then Yusuf took from Ishaq and invented a complete lean pen, excessively complete and open. It pleased Dhu al-Ri'asatayn al-Fadl bin Sahl, so he ordered the royal books to be written with it, and it was named the Ri'asi Pen (2).
foot_note:
1. He is Al-Dahhak bin Ajlan, was in the early Abbasid Caliphate, Ibn al-Nadim 10 and Subh al-A'sha 3: 12. He was from the people of Sham. 
2. Subh al-A'sha: "Some later scholars said: And I think it is the Tawqi'at (Signature) pen."

Wajh al-Na'jah was foremost in the Jalil pen, and Abu Zarjan (1) was foremost in the Half pen. Ahmad bin Hafs (2) was the sweetest of writers in handwriting in the Thuluth pen.
The Vizier (3) said: The meaning of the writers' saying Half pen, Third pen, and Two-Thirds pen, goes back to the origin. That is that script has two genera from the fourteen (4) methods which are the origins, they are like two edges for it. One is the Tumar pen, which is a completely spread pen with nothing round in it, and the old Madini Mushafs were often written with it. And another pen called Ghubar al-Halbah, which is a completely round pen with nothing straight in it. All pens are taken from the straight and the round in different ratios. Whatever has straight lines equal to round lines is called the Half pen. If the straight lines in it are one third, it is called the Third pen. If the straight lines in it are two thirds, it is called the Two-Thirds pen. Upon this, these pens are composed.
Hayyun bin Amr, the brother of Al-Ahwal, excelled in it, and he was a better calligrapher than his brother.
Then the quality of handwriting, its beauty, and its editing ended at the beginning of the three hundreds with the master in this art, the Vizier Abu Ali Muhammad bin al-Hasan bin Muqla the Scribe, his death was in the year 328. Then to his two students Muhammad bin Asad al-Ghafiqi and Muhammad al-Simsani. From them, the great master Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Hilal al-Baghdadi known as Ibn al-Bawwab took it. From him, Muhammad bin Mansur

2. Subh al-A'sha: "Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Hafs known as Zaqif."

Ibn Abd al-Malik took it, and from him the Sheikhah, Scribe, and Muhaddithah Zaynab - also called Fatimah - who is the daughter of Sheikh Abu al-Faraj, known as Shuhda bint al-Abari (1). Al-Hafiz al-Dhahabi wrote her biography in his history.
Among those who perfected under her was Sheikh Abu al-Durr Amin al-Din Yaqut bin Abdullah al-Mawsili the Scribe, also known as al-Nuri, al-Malaki (2), and al-Sharafi. His handwriting spread in the horizons, and in his late time there was no one who approached him in beauty of handwriting nor anyone who performed Ibn al-Bawwab's method in Naskh like him, with abundant virtue. He was fond of copying Sahih al-Jawhari, so he wrote many copies of it, each one in a volume, each copy sold for one hundred dinars. I saw a copy of it in Egypt. His death was in the year 618 in Mosul.
As for Yaqut al-Rumi, also known as al-Hamawi, his death was in the year 626 in Aleppo at fifty-two (3) years old.
Among those who wrote under the mentioned Yaqut was Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Zanki known as "al-Wali al-Ajami". I found in the history of Al-Hafiz al-Sakhawi that al-Wali al-Ajami took from Shuhda the Scribe without the mediation of Yaqut.
Then the quality of handwriting ended with Sheikh "Afif al-Din Muhammad al-Halabi", also known as al-Shirazi. His son "Imad al-Din Muhammad" took from him, and he was the Imam of grammarians and scribes in his time.
Among those who wrote under him was the Allamah Imam Shams al-Din "Muhammad bin Ali bin Abi Raqabah (4)".

And from him the Allamah Imam "Abu Ali Muhammad bin Ahmad bin al-Zaftawi" the teacher (1). He was born in the year 750 and heard Hadith from Khalil bin Tarantay (2). He authored "Minhaj al-Isabah" in the science of calligraphy, and the people of Egypt benefited from it. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar wrote under him, and that suffices as an honor. He died in the year 806. His companion in writing under his sheikhs was Imam Shihab al-Din Ghazi.
And from him his student Imam Nur al-Din al-Wasimi. And under him wrote Imam Zayn al-Din Abd al-Rahman bin Yusuf al-Qahiri, known as "Ibn al-Sa'igh", the Sheikh of this art absolutely. He was born in Egypt in the year 769 and adhered to his mentioned sheikh in perfecting the Naskh pen until he surpassed him. He loved the method of Ibn al-Afif, so he followed it and benefited in it from Abu Ali al-Zaftawi al-Masri. Al-Zayn came to have a method extracted from the methods of Ibn al-Afif and Ghazi, as happened to Ghazi, his sheikh's sheikh. For he wrote first under Ibn Abi Raqabah, the sheikh of the mentioned al-Zaftawi and student of Ibn al-Afif, then Ghazi shifted from the method of Ibn al-Afif, his sheikh's sheikh, to a method he generated between it and the method of al-Wali al-Ajami, so he surpassed the people of his time in beauty of handwriting. People benefited from Ibn al-Sa'igh layer after layer; he copied several Mushafs and other books and creeds, and became the Sheikh of scribes in his time. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar testified to

Then the quality and beauty of handwriting ended after Ibn al-Sa'igh and his layer with the Qibla of scribes, and the Sheikh of this pleasant art, to whose majesty pens prostrated, and on whose preference the elite and general public agreed, the unique Imam, and the singular magnanimous one, our master the Sheikh of Sheikhs, Sheikh Hamdullah son of Sheikh Mustafa al-Amasi (1), known as "Ibn al-Sheikh", may Allah cover him with His mercy. He was born approximately in the year 847, two or three years after the death of Ibn al-Sa'igh. He is the one who devised these Samuts (styles/methods) (2) known in our time from the scripts of the predecessors as happened to others before him who invented the method between two methods, until he excelled the scribes of his time, and surpassed the people of his era and age.
His father was a righteous man authorized in the path of the Suhrawardi Sheikhs. His gaze fell upon his mentioned son until he surpassed in high ranks. It suffices him as pride that there is no Sanad (chain) on earth now relied upon except from his path, nor a method desired among the people of the art except from his verification and scrutiny.
Among his contemporaries were two men from the great scribes of their time, namely "Yahya al-Rumi" and "Ali bin Yahya". The latter's death was in the year 866.
It is said that the Sheikh wrote under "Khair al-Din al-Mar'ashi", who died in the year 896. And he under "Abdullah al-Sayrafi", and he under "Ahmad bin Ali" known as Tayyib Shah al-Suhrawardi, and he under "Muhammad al-Badashi al-Ajami", and he under "al-Wali al-Ajami".
It is said that the Sheikh, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, wrote with his noble hand forty-four Mushafs and a copy of the book Al-Masabih by al-Baghawi, and the book Al-Mashariq by al-Saghani, both in Gazelle

While he was in his eighty-eighth year, an incident of trembling occurred in his head. As for his hand at the time of writing, it never trembled, such that his handwriting at the end of his life matched his handwriting in his youth. Kings served him and held the inkwell for him in his hands, and he was given acceptance and fame such as no one before him nor after him was given. His karamat (miracles) are famous. He died approximately in the year 957 at one hundred and ten years old. He was buried in Uskudar in a platform opposite the Takiyya known as Karaca Ahmad, during the time of Sultan Abu al-Fath Suleiman Khan son of Selim Khan, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him (1).
Then the quality and beauty of handwriting ended with his students. They are "Muhyi al-Din Jalal Zadeh" who lived a hundred years and wrote ninety-seven Mushafs, and "Jamal al-Din al-Amasi" and his brother "Abdullah", each of whom lived eighty years. However, the rules of these three lean more towards the rules of Yaqut al-Musta'simi.
Among the special students of the Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, was "Husam al-Din Khalifa". He was skilled in the six scripts and plain Naskh. He imitated his sheikh's method until many discriminators and identifiers erred in distinguishing between their handwritings. He lived sixty-seven years and wrote eighty-nine Mushafs.
Among them was "Shukrullah Khalifa", who was skilled in the six scripts and plain Naskh and wrote several Mushafs and litanies.

Among them was "Rajab Khalifa", who was skilled in the six scripts and plain Naskh, and wrote ninety-three Mushafs and a number of Surat Al-An'am and litanies.
In the late era of the Sheikh, there was a man among those skilled in calligraphy named "Ahmad Effendi Karahisari". It is said that the Sheikh granted him Ijazah in writing, but in his later years he leaned towards Yaqut's method and combined both methods. He wrote a number of Mushafs and litanies. He died in the year 963.
Among his special students was "Hussein Chelebi Khalifa", who revived his sheikh's method and wrote several Mushafs.
Then came after him "Deli Yusuf Effendi" who excelled, because he combined his sheikh's method and the Hamdi method, so he became extremely accepted, and wrote several Mushafs in this method.
Then came after him "Kara Ali Effendi", then after him "Tekneci Hasan Chelebi", and no one became famous after him in this chain.
Among the distinguished in the era of these was the Sheikh's own son, the skilled, precise Imam "Mustafa Dede", known like his father as Ibn al-Sheikh. His father named him with his father's name for blessing. He had excelled during his father's life in good handwriting, and the virtuous testified for him. His father granted him Ijazah in writing, and he was skilled in the six scripts like his father. He wrote several Mushafs, litanies, and supplications. He died at forty years old and was buried next to his father in Uskudar.
Among those in his era from the senior students of his father was the skilled Imam Mahmoud Effendi famous as "Topçulu". He was famous for good imitation of the Sheikh, wrote several Noble Mushafs, Al-An'am, and Adhkar.
In his era were "Abd al-Karim Khalifa" known as Wiqayah Zadeh, and "Shukr Allah

Among those famous in their time was "Abdullah Effendi al-Qirimi". He wrote in the Sheikh's method by stealing from his scripts, because it is said: He requested teaching and Ijazah from the Sheikh but he did not agree. He strove until he became proficient in the art, wrote several Mushafs, and extracted for himself a method derived between the Sheikh's method and Ahmad Tayyib Shah's method, inventing from them a type of Thuluth. But his status fell between the writers and Bahais, and he became of those wavering between that, neither to these nor to those.
Among those who revived his method after him was a man named "Amrullah Effendi". He imitated him in his derived method with much leaning towards the Hamdi method, due to the precision of his nature and subtlety of his thought, so praise and acceptance of him was good. He wrote with that several Mushafs, Al-An'am, and Adhkar.
Then the quality of handwriting ended after these with the skilled Imam "Pir Effendi", who is the Sheikh's grandson. His father Dervish Muhammad granted him Ijazah in writing. He revived the method of his ancestors, while adhering to its limits, and wrote several Mushafs and Al-An'am.
Among those who wrote under him was his contemporary the skilled Imam "Hassan Effendi" known as "Uskudari Hasan Chelebi". He assumed the Sheikhdom of the Serai after his sheikh, and wrote several Mushafs, Al-An'am, and Adhkar.
From him the precise, perfecting Imam "Khalid Effendi" known as Al-Aziz took. His sheikh Al-Uskudari granted him Ijazah in writing, and he wrote several Mushafs, Adhkar, and Surat Al-An'am.
In his era among the skilled was "Kara Hussein Effendi". He assumed the Sheikhdom of the Agha's office, and wrote several Mushafs and Adhkar. He was described with excessive beauty, and some of his students testified to his karamah (miracle).

Then the quality of handwriting ended with the skilled, precise Imam, the late "Dervish Ali Effendi" nicknamed the Second Sheikh. He wrote first under the mentioned Kara Hussein Effendi, and after his death obtained completion and Ijazah at the hands of Khalid Al-Aziz. He wrote eighty-eight Mushafs and a number of Surat Al-An'am, litanies, and Adhkar. His handwriting is the reliance in this time of ours. He died in the year 1086 at eighty-seven years old. Among his karamat is that he raised his index finger after his death when the washer said the Shahadah, and he was washed with water boiled with the shavings of his pens (1).
Among his contemporary calligraphers was Ramadan bin Ismail. It is said he wrote three hundred and sixty Mushafs, and a number of Surat Al-An'am and Adhkar. His death was in the year 1097.
Also among the contemporaries were Ali Effendi Nefeszadeh, Omar Bey Nasuhpashazadeh, Muhammad Effendi the Imam, Ali Effendi Kasikcizade, Ahmad Effendi Kazkazbanzadeh, Muhammad Effendi Nakkashzadeh, Khalil Effendi nicknamed Al-Hafiz, Muhammad Effendi Arabzadeh who died in 1122, and Muhammad Effendi Khawajahzadeh. It is said that Dervish Ali granted Ijazah to these last two.
Among them Ismail Effendi Turk, who died drowned in the sea in the year 1085. And Yusuf Effendi who died in the year 1119. These two were in Egypt.
Then the quality of handwriting ended with (the students of Dervish Ali), among them Mustafa Effendi al-Ayyubi known as Suyolcuzade, his death was in the year 1099.

Conclusion
We ask Allah for a good ending. It has two sections:
First: In explaining the etiquette of the student with the Sheikh
Know that the seeker of this art and the one desiring it must have a Sheikh who shows him the subtleties of the art, verifies its realities for him, reveals its symbols to him, opens its puzzles for him, and brings its intricacies closer to him. It has been reported in some traditions, from some of the righteous: "Were it not for the educator, I would not have known my Lord."
If Allah facilitates a teacher for him, he has conditions with him. Among them is preserving his status in absence and presence as much as possible. He should not raise his voice over his voice, nor say to him about anything he said: Why this? If something confuses him, he asks for its clarification with politeness.
Among them is not conversing with anyone beside him in his presence except for a necessary matter.
Among them is not to laugh in the presence of his teacher except smiling for a reason.
Among them is not anticipating his speech, but remaining silent until he finishes what he is saying.
Among them is sitting in his presence like the posture of Tashahhud, stealing glances at his teacher's face.
Among them is not quarreling with any of his teacher's followers and those attributed to him.
Among them is preserving his belongings from boldness against them; he should not wear his clothes or shoes, ride his mount, sit on his prayer rug, or drink from the vessel prepared for him unless he permits him in any of that.
Among them is to persist in practice and diligence in what the teacher tells him and commands him.
These are the etiquettes of the student with the teacher. Whoever is afflicted with the disruption of any of them out of negligence or heedlessness will never succeed.
Second: Advice for all calligraphers
Allah Almighty said in His Aziz Book: "And the life of this world is only the enjoyment of deception."
The knowers of this art mentioned that one of the greatest causes of completion for the student in this

Whenever he is negligent in the matter of his self, and arrogant over the sons of his gender, he is punished with deprivation and whispers, and falls from his rank that he was in with Allah and with people.
We ask Allah for pardon and satisfaction, and overlooking what has passed. Indeed, He is over all things competent, and worthy of every bounty. Allah is sufficient for us, and [He is] the best Disposer of affairs. There is no power and no strength except in Allah, the Most High, the Great.
May Allah bless our master and lord Muhammad and his family and companions and grant them peace abundantly until the Day of Judgment.
